Award.AwardTitle: Measurement of the Gravitostatic Aharonov-Bohn Effect
Award.AbstractNarration:
Of the fundamental forces, gravity is probably the one most familiar in everyday life, yet its physics is the least well understood. For one, it does not fit into the standard model of particle physics, which is based on quantum mechanics. In addition, the action of gravity in quantum mechanics has been relatively elusive to experimental measurement. One of the most important challenges in physics is thus to find new ways to investigate how gravity affects quantum systems. The group will give a demonstration of the so-called Aharonov-Bohm effect (AB effect) for gravity. In classical physics, the interaction between two objects can be described equivalently based on forces or on potential energies. Aharonov and Bohm, however, pointed out that in quantum mechanics, two objects can influence each other even if there are zero forces between them. This has been verified experimentally for electromagnetic forces and potentials. The group will construct a specialized apparatus to investigate whether there is an analogous Aharonov-Bohm effect for gravity. This will demonstrate that gravity affects a quantum system even when it does not cause any classical force; that knowledge of the classical gravitational force acting locally on a particle is not sufficient to predict the particle's quantum-mechanical behavior; and help develop a new way of measuring Newton's gravitational constant G. Paraphrasing R. P. Feynman, for a long time it was believed that potentials were not "real", since they could be replaced by force fields in the description of any observable phenomenon then known. However, the AB effect has established that potentials are real, and forces are slowly disappearing from the modern expression of physical law. The group is collaborating with industrial partners to apply the techniques developed in this work in the production of advanced inertial sensors for improved navigation and positioning.

The experiment will be based on laser-cooled cesium atoms held in an optical lattice, inside a special arrangement of two spherical masses that produce a "W"-shaped gravitational potential. The atoms will be at extrema of the gravitational potential, so that there will be no net force between the spherical masses and the atoms. Nevertheless, the masses should cause a relative phase shift of the atomic matter waves. The group will experimentally demonstrate the distinguishing features of the AB effect, such as nonlocality and nondispersiveness. The optical lattice will be a standing wave inside a Fabry-Perot cavity, to control the optical wave-fronts and provide laser intensity enhancement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The weakness of gravity has made it relatively elusive to experimental measurement. Gravity and hypothetical “fifth” forces of gravitational strengthremain the only ones that cannot be measured directly between microscopic particles.  The traditional experimental methods, from astronomy to torsion balances, use macroscopic masses to both generate the gravitational field and to probe it. Matter-wave interferometers have used individual neutrons and atoms to probe the field, but initially, the gravitational fields used were generated by the entire earth. As the technology improved, the gravitational field arising from hundreds of kilograms of artificial source masses was measured with atom interferometry, which made it possible to measure Newton’s gravitational constant G.

With NSF support, we have built the first atom interferometer that is able to measure the gravitational force between atoms and cm-sized test masses inside the vacuum chamber. The interferometer uses resonant light in a stable Fabry-Perot cavity to address the atoms. This offers substantial advantages for the construction of high-performance atom interferometers, including laser intensity enhancement, spatial filtering, and a precise beam geometry. It enables new techniques such as low-power beam splitters (< 100 μW) with large momentum transfer or new self-aligned interferometer geometries utilizing the transverse modes of the optical cavity. This work has been published in PRL.

While we were preparing this instrument, we learned that atom interferometry could help to investigate the dark sector, specifically chameleon theories of dark energy. We decided to pursue this avenue while continuing to improve the setup to eventually measure the Aharonov-Bohm effect. We configured the interferometer so that it could search for chameleons with high sensitivity. Probing the force with atomic test particles as opposed to macroscopic objects alleviates the screening, as the low density of the atomic cloud allows the chameleon field to maintain a long range, compared to the size of the apparatus.

The measurement uses the cavity-based atom interferometer to measure the acceleration of the atoms, and thus the force between cesium-133 atoms and an aluminum sphere. Earth’s gravity is suppressed by moving the test mass every 5 minutes between a “far” and a “close” position and comparing the results. Our sensitivity surpasses that of previous experiments by factors of thousands, including experiments based on atomic structure, Casimir-effect measurements, torsion balances, and neutron interferometers.

As an additional application, we have demonstrated a force arising from blackbody radiation of a heated sphere. The existence of such a force was theoretically predicted, but has not been confirmed experimentally before our experiment.  

This development will also allow us to measure new effects of gravity: In analogy to electromagnetism, there should be Aharonov-Bohm effects of gravity, defined in the broadest sense as nonclassical effects of gravity on a quantum state in the absence of any classically measurable forces. A pair of test masses creates a w-shaped gravitational potential, which was inaccessible in previous atom interferometer geometries. Placing atomic wave packets in a superposition of being at maximum and minimum potential will allow us to measure a phase shift caused by the gravitational potential difference. It would create a new way to study the intersection of quantum mechanics and gravity, and enable a new type of precision measurement of the gravitational constant. 

In analogy to the electromagnetic Aharonov-Bohm effect, knowledge of the local gravitational field is not sufficient to predict the particle’s quantum-mechanical behavior. Paraphrasing R. P. Feynman, for a long time it was believed that the electromagnetic potentials V and A were not “real,” since they could be replaced by the E and B fields in the description of any observable phenomenon then known. However, the AB effect in quantum mechanics has established that V and A are “real,” and the fields E and B are slowly disappearing from the modern expression of physical law.

Broader Impact

Methods developed for the cavity interferometer might be important for measuring scalar and tensor polarizability, entanglement in atom interferometry, and large-scale interferometers for tests of the equivalence principle. They are widely seen as solutions to decoherence in atom interferometers using optical lattices. 

The atom interferometry technique to look for chameleons has spawned a wave of new laboratory and astrophysical tests of gravity using atom interferometry and is promising the largest reduction in the upper bound on the coupling to matter. Exact solutions and numerical codes for calculating chameleon fields are being developed, and re-analyses of our experiment shows its sensitivity to other types of "exotic physics" as well. Experiments with microspheres have been conducted, and new proposed atom interferometers and space-based chameleon experiments have also been envisioned.

This project has helped to launch several careers. Numerous undergraduates went on to prestigious graduate schools. Paul Hamilton, the postdoc who brought the cavity interferometer to live and obtained the constraints on chameleon fields, has earned an Assistant Professor of Physics position at UCLA.
